Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Situation2: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Story: I glance at my phone on the dashboard, the screen lighting up with another message from Alex: “Can we talk tonight? I can’t keep arguing like this.” My chest tightens. We’ve been fighting about money all week, and I know he expects me to help fix things, to be the understanding girlfriend who smooths things over. But right now, I’m behind the wheel, focused on the road, my passenger in the back humming along to the radio, relaxed, in no rush. As a taxi driver, I’m supposed to be calm, attentive, and get them to their meeting safely and on time. I can’t let my personal life bleed into my work, but my mind keeps drifting back to Alex’s words, the tension in his voice. I grip the steering wheel tighter, feeling the weight of both roles pressing down on me. I want to pull over and call him, to try and make things right, but I also have a responsibility to my passenger. The city blurs past, and I’m caught between the demands of love and duty, unsure which to answer first.
